Serbian drug for ranitidine ulcer withdrawn in Russia

A Serbian drug for the treatment of gastric ulcer Ranitidin containing a dangerous substance is withdrawn from circulation, according to an information letter on the Roszdravnadzor website. Sputnik reported earlier that Lithuania had banned the sale of medicines containing the active substance ranitidine hydrochloride, the decision was made because due to the presence in it of an impurity of N-nitrosodimethylamine (NDMA), which is a carcinogen that affects the liver. Roszdravnadzor asked manufacturers and importers by October 2 to provide information on decisions taken regarding drugs. Manufacturers of Zantak and Ranitidine drugs manufactured in Russia announced in early October that they were withdrawing drugs from circulation. “The Federal Service for Supervision of Healthcare reports on the manufacturer’s decision to initiate a withdrawal procedure from the circulation of the Ranitidin drug ... (Serbia ), in connection with the decision of the special committee of the European Directorate for the Quality of Medical Products (EDQM) on the suspension of the certificate of suitability for the substance "Ranitidine hydrochloride" manufactured by "Saraka Laboratories L limited "(India)," the report said.
On September 23, EDQM suspended the certificate for ranitidine hydrochloride. Against this background, the medicine was withdrawn in Germany, Switzerland, Finland, Croatia, Czech Republic, Hungary, Denmark, Canada, Italy, Spain, Poland, Portugal, Slovenia and Singapore. Ranitidine is a medicine used to reduce high levels of stomach acid in the treatment of short-term problems with stomach (without a prescription) and in the prevention and treatment of ulcers (with a prescription).
Source: RIA Novosti
